content: A functional dependency exists when the value of one field is completely determined by the value of another.

title: GRANT
content: A keyword (part of the DCL category) that is used to give privileges for certain tasks to a specified user or role.

title: GROUP BY clause
content: A clause in an SQL statement that allows you to specify how the data should be grouped in the SELECT query’s output.

title: Hash join
content: A hash join is where two tables are joined based on a hashing algorithm. You may see this in your Explain Plan output.

title: HAVING Clause
content: This clause allows you to limit the rows returned by a SELECT query after the GROUP BY clause is applied. It is often used with aggregate functions.

title: Heap-organized table
content: A heap-organized table is a table in Oracle where the rows are not stored in any particular order. When a specific order is required, it is retrieved using a SELECT query with an ORDER BY clause.

title: Hint
content: A hint is a special keyword that can be used in a query to alter the execution plan.

title: Histogram
content: A graph that shows different sizes depending on the frequency of a value in a table.

title: IDE
content: IDE stands for Integrated Development Environment, and it is software that allows developers to write code and perform many other tasks for application development.

title: IF THEN ELSE
content: A concept of performing different logic depending on a condition.

title: Index
content: An object on the database that contains references to each value in a field that lets you quickly locate records in a table.

title: Index-organized table
content: An index-organized table (or IOT) is a type of table that stores the primary key and non-key data stored in a B-tree structure.

title: Inline view
content: A SELECT statement which is in the FROM clause of another SELECT statement. It is treated like a view but is not stored as a database object.

title: Inner Join
content: A type of join where the results of the joined tables are shown where the fields match in both columns. If there is a record in one table but not the other, then data for both records is not shown.

title: INSERT
content: An SQL command for adding data to a table.

title: INTERSECT
content: A set operator in SQL that allows you to view the results of one query that exist in the results of another query.

title: Interval
content: A data type in Oracle that stores a duration of time. It is different to a date or timestamp, which store a period in time.

title: Isolation level
content: An isolation level is a property that can be set on a session that determines what kind of data can be seen.

title: JDBC
content: JDBC stands for Java Database Connectivity, and is a standard API that allows Java programs to access databases.

title: JDK
content: JDK stands for Java Development Kit, and it is a software development environment that’s used for developing Java applications.

title: Join
content: The concept of linking two tables together on related field, so a query can retrieve data from two tables. It’s one of the main features of relational databases.

title: Keyword
content: The range of reserved words that are used by the database to process SQL queries. They include commands (such as SELECT and INSERT), set operators (such as UNION) and other words such as JOIN and FROM.

title: LIKE
content: A keyword that allows you to compare on partial strings. It is often used in the WHERE clause and uses either % wildcards or _ wildcards for string comparison.

title: Listener
content: An Oracle process for listening for incoming database connections on the server.

title: Literal
content: A number, character, or string that is enclosed in single quotes in a query.

title: LOB
content: LOB stands for Large Object and is implemented in Oracle as CLOB, NCLOB, or BLOB data types.

title: Lock
content: A feature of a database that allows concurrency control and data consistency.

title: Logical operator
content: A logical operator is a keyword that allows two expressions to be compared and an overall value of TRUE or FALSE to be returned.

title: Many to Many Relationship
content: A type of relationship between two tables that means many records in one table can relate to many records in another table.

title: Materialized View
content: A materialized view is a type of view in a database where the data is stored along with the query that created it.

title: Merge
content: An SQL command that allows you to check if data exists, insert data into a table if the data does not exist, and update the data if it does exist. This is all done in a single command and is an efficient command used in ETL processes.

title: Metadata
content: Data about data. Metadata is what’s stored in the data dictionary, as it is data about the tables and objects in the database.

title: MINUS
content: A set operator that allows you to see the results of one query that don’t exist in another query.

title: Multi-row subquery
content: A subquery that returns more than one row. This is often handled with keywords such as IN, NOT IN, > ALL, < ANY.

title: Multivalued attribute
content: An attribute that has a value of a set of values. Oracle includes the Nested Table and VARRAY data types for this.

title: Mutating Table
content: A mutating table is a table that is being changed.

title: Natural Join
content: A join type where two tables are joined without specifying the columns. The columns that have the same names in both tables are used as the join fields.

title: Natural key
content: A natural key is a primary key made up of columns already in the table.

title: NCHAR
content: An Oracle datatype, similar to CHAR, but can hold Unicode characters. It has a fixed length, just like the CHAR data type.

title: Nested Table
content: An Oracle data type that can support entire tables of values in a single column.

title: NEXTVAL
content: A property of a sequence that increments the current sequence value and returns it. Often used for inserting primary key values into a table.

title: NLS
content: NLS stands for National Language Support), and it is used to define the date, number, currency, and language settings for different nations.

title: Non-equi-join
content: A type of join condition where the columns being compared are not equal.

title: Normalization
content: The process of modifying a database design to align with a standard set of rules and make it ideal for transactions.

title: NULLIF
content: A function that returns NULL if the two expressions are equal, but returns the first expression if they are not.

title: Number
content: An SQL datatype used for storing whole numbers and decimal numbers.

title: NVARCHAR2
content: An Oracle data type that stores a variable-length string, like VARCHAR2, but can store Unicode characters.

title: OBIEE
content: OBIEE stands for Oracle Business Intelligence Enterprise Edition. It’s a set of business intelligence and analytics platforms that perform business intelligence functions on a data warehouse.

title: OCA
content: OCA stands for Oracle Certified Associate. It is the entry-level Oracle DBA certification. Once you have this certification, you have the skills for a junior level DBA.

title: OCM
content: OCM stands for Oracle Certified Master, and it is the third level of the DBA certification track and is targeted to senior DBAs and consultants.

title: OCP
content: OCP stands for Oracle Certified Professional, and is the second certification on the Oracle DBA track. It is targeted to mid to senior level DBAs.

title: ODI
content: ODI stands for Oracle Data Integrator, and is an ETL tool used to move data between different systems.

title: OLAP
content: OLAP stands for Online Analytical Processing, and is a type of system that allows users to analyse and manipulate the display of data to make decisions.

title: OLTP
content: OLTP stands for Online Transactional Processing, and is a type of system that allows for large numbers of transactions (insert, update, delete, and select) to be performed on a system.

title: On Delete Cascade
content: A setting when creating a foreign key that says if a record in the parent table is deleted, then the corresponding records in the child table are also deleted.

title: One to Many Relationship
content: A type of relationship where a record in one table can relate to many records in another table.

title: One to One Relationship
content: A type of relationship where a record in one table can have only one record in another table, in both directions.

title: Operator
content: A symbol (>, =, <=, etc) or keyword (NOT, IN, ALL, UNION) that is placed between expressions to compare them.

title: Oracle Fusion
content: A set of applications that help with enterprise resource planning. It is the replacement for EBS (Oracle E-Business Suite), and includes financials, supply chain management, HR, and many other areas.

title: ORACLE_HOME
content: The directory or environment variable that points to where Oracle is installed.

title: OTN
content: OTN stands for Oracle Technology Network and is Oracle’s community website. It includes forums and product documentation.

title: Outer Join
content: A type of join where records from one table are shown, and if there are records in the second table, they are shown, but if no records match, then show a NULL value.

title: Package
content: A collection of related PL/SQL code (functions and procedures) into a single unit. Packages are used to improve the security and design of your code.

title: PGA
content: PGA stands for Process Global Area, and is an area in RAM that stores data for a single process.

title: PLS_INTEGER
content: A data type, only available in PL/SQL, that is used for storing signed integers.

title: Pragma
content: A pragma is a compiler directive, or hint, that is used to provide an instruction to the compiler.

title: Predicate
content: The expression used in a WHERE clause to specify which rows should be returned.

title: Primary Key
content: A field in a table that is used to uniquely identify a row.

title: Privilege
content: A permission that can be granted to or revoked from a specific user or role, which allows the user or role to perform certain actions.

title: Procedure
content: A stored piece of procedural code that allows parameters to be provided and returned, and perform complex functionality.

title: Pseudocolumn
content: A column that is automatically added to every database table to display data about the record.

title: Query
content: A collection of SQL keywords which allows for a specific action to be taken. A query is run on its own as part of a transaction.

title: RAC
content: RAC stands for Oracle Real Application Clusters. It is a database solution that allows more than one system to share a single Oracle database.

title: RAW
content: An old Oracle data type used to store binary data, such as images or audio. It has been replaced by the BLOB data type.

title: RBO
content: Stands for Rules-Based Optimizer, and is a query optimizer that uses different rules to define the best query execution plan.

title: RDBMS
content: RDBMS stands for Relational Database Management System and is a type of DBMS where the tables are organised according to relationships between the data.

title: REF CURSOR
content: A data type that holds a cursor value. It is used to pass the single cursor object to a different part of the code, instead of the individual values within it.

title: Relation
content: A mathematical term for a table.

title: Relationship
content: The link or association between two entities in an ERD or tables in a database.

title: REVOKE
content: A command used to remove a privilege from a user or role. The opposite of a GRANT command.

title: RMAN
content: RMAN stands for Recovery Manager and is a utility used to backup, restore, clone, and recover Oracle databases.

title: Role
content: A group of privileges that can be granted or revoked from users.

title: ROLLBACK
content: A command used to undo any changes made to the data in the tables during your current transaction. The opposite of the COMMIT keyword.

title: Rollback segment
content: An object that contains images of before data was written to the database. They are used to undo changes when a transaction is rolled back.

title: ROWID
content: A value for a row that is unique within the database. It contains a 10-byte character value that represents the location on the physical disk that the row lives.

title: ROWNUM
content: A pseudocolumn that shows the row’s position in a result set.

title: Savepoint
content: A savepoint is a marker in a transaction that can be set as a point to roll back to at a later time.

title: Schema
content: A schema is the set of objects (tables, views, sequences) that belong to a user account.

title: SCN
content: SCN stands for System Change Number and represents a unique number for every time a commit is made.

title: Second Normal Form (2NF)
content: The second stage of normalization. A database is in second normal form if it meets the rules of first normal form, and “all of the non-key attributes are dependent on the primary key”.

title: Segment
content: A database object that has space allocated to it.

title: SELECT
content: An SQL keyword for viewing data in the database.

title: Self Join
content: A type of join where you join a table to itself.

title: Sequence
content: A database object that is used to generate unique numbers. It’s great for primary key values and IDs, and ensures different transactions get different values. Read more about sequences here.

title: Session
content: The set of events that happen from when a user connects to a database to when the user disconnects from the database.

title: SGA
content: SGA stands for System Global Area. It forms part of the RAM and contains all of the information needed to operate the instance.

title: SID
content: SID stands for System Identifier, and it uniquely identifies an Oracle database instance on a system.

title: Single-row subquery
content: A subquery that always returns a single row, either using a unique constraint in the WHERE clause or an aggregate function.

title: SQL
content: SQL stands for Structured Query Language and is the language used to communicate with a database.

title: SQLCODE
content: An Oracle function that returns the number code for the most recent exception. The SQLCODE function is often used along with the SQLERRM function.

title: Star schema
content: A database design for data warehouses and data marts that contains a single fact table and multiple dimension tables linked to it.

title: Subquery
content: A SELECT query that is run inside another query. Often used to get the results of one query and use it as an input into another query.

title: Surrogate key
content: A new field created for the purpose of a primary key for a table, instead of using an existing field.

title: Synonym
content: A database object that is a pointer to another object, such as a table or view.

title: SYS
content: The username and schema that contains the data dictionary in Oracle.

title: Table-level constraint
content: A constraint that is defined at the table level, after all of the columns have been defined.

title: Tablespace
content: A logical storage unit that stores all of the data for the tables.

title: Third normal form (3NF)
content: The third and ideal stage of normalization.

title: TIMESTAMP
content: A data type in Oracle that stores the date, time, and fractional time in seconds.

title: TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE
content: A data type in Oracle that stores the date, time, fractional time in seconds, and a timezone value.

title: TKProf
content: TKProf is an Oracle utility used to format the output of SQL Trace into something that’s more readable.

title: TNS
content: TNS stands for Transparent Network Substrate, and is a technology for connecting to Oracle databases.

title: TNSNAMES.ora
content: A file that contains network service names and how they map to connection descriptors or connection strings.

title: Toad
content: An IDE for SQL developers, allowing developers to connect to an Oracle database, write and run queries, and much more.

title: Transaction
content: A single unit of work that must be saved or rolled back in its entirety. Transactions start when a user connects to a database and end when a user commits or rolls back.

title: Transitive dependency
content: Transitive dependency means that one attribute determines a second attribute indirectly, as it involves a third attribute in the middle.

title: Trigger
content: A database object that is attached to a table that is called when a row is inserted, updated, or deleted. Triggers contain procedural code and allow you to check that changes are correct or add in any data that needs to be there but is not specified by the SQL statement.

title: TRUNCATE
content: An SQL statement that deletes all data from a table. Generally faster than a DELETE statement as there is no log and the transaction is committed.

title: Tuple
content: Another name for a row in a table. A tuple exists in a relation.

title: UDT
content: UDT stands for User Defined Type and is a type that is created by a user in a PL/SQL program.

title: UID
content: UID stands for User Identification and is a pseudocolumn that holds a numeric value for the currently logged-in user.

title: UML
content: UML stands for Unified Modelling Language, and it is a general-purpose modelling language for visualizing the design of a system.

title: UNION
content: The UNION keyword is a set operator that allows for the results of one query to be combined with the results of another query, and duplicates removed.

title: UNION ALL
content: The UNION ALL keyword is a set operator that allows for the results of one query to be combined with the results of another query, and duplicates kept.

title: Unique key/Unique constraint
content: A unique key, or unique constraint, is a constraint that ensures only unique values are entered into the column specified.

title: UPDATE
content: An SQL command used for making changes to data that exists in a table already.

title: User
content: It can refer to a user account on the database that someone logs in as.

title: VARCHAR
content: A data type in the SQL standard that allows for variable-length character data to be stored.

title: VARCHAR2
content: A variable length data type for holding character data.

title: VARRAY
content: A data type used to support a column that contains multiple values. Kind of like an array.

title: View
content: A SELECT query stored on the database, but has a name and is treated like a table. Other queries can select from this view, and the underlying query is run each time.

title: Wildcard
content: A character that can be substituted for one or more characters.

title: XE
content: XE stands for Express Edition, and it refers to the freely available Oracle database.

title: Accuracy
content: Percentage of correct predictions made by the model.

title: Algorithm
content: A method, function, or series of instructions used to generate a machine learning model. Examples include linear regression, decision trees, support vector machines, and neural networks.

title: Attribute
content: A quality describing an observation (e.g. color, size, weight). In Excel terms, these are column headers.

title: Bias metric
content:
What is the average difference between your predictions and the correct value for that observation?

Low bias could mean every prediction is correct. It could also mean half of your predictions are above their actual values and half are below, in equal proportion, resulting in low average difference.
High bias (with low variance) suggests your model may be underfitting and you’re using the wrong architecture for the job.

title: Bias term
content: Allow models to represent patterns that do not pass through the origin. For example, if all my features were 0, would my output also be zero? Is it possible there is some base value upon which my features have an effect? Bias terms typically accompany weights and are attached to neurons or filters.

title: Categorical Variables
content: Variables with a discrete set of possible values. Can be ordinal (order matters) or nominal (order doesn’t matter).

title: Classification
content:
Predicting a categorical output.

Binary classification predicts one of two possible outcomes (e.g. is the email spam or not spam?)
Multi-class classification predicts one of multiple possible outcomes (e.g. is this a photo of a cat, dog, horse or human?)

title: Classification Threshold
content: The lowest probability value at which we’re comfortable asserting a positive classification. For example, if the predicted probability of being diabetic is > 50%, return True, otherwise return False.

title: Clustering
content: Unsupervised grouping of data into buckets.

title: Confusion Matrix
content:
Table that describes the performance of a classification model by grouping predictions into 4 categories.

True Positives: we correctly predicted they do have diabetes
True Negatives: we correctly predicted they don’t have diabetes
False Positives: we incorrectly predicted they do have diabetes (Type I error)
False Negatives: we incorrectly predicted they don’t have diabetes (Type II error)

title: Continuous Variables
content: Variables with a range of possible values defined by a number scale (e.g. sales, lifespan).

title: Convergence
content: A state reached during the training of a model when the loss changes very little between each iteration.

title: Deduction
content: A top-down approach to answering questions or solving problems. A logic technique that starts with a theory and tests that theory with observations to derive a conclusion. E.g. We suspect X, but we need to test our hypothesis before coming to any conclusions.

title: Deep Learning
content: Deep Learning is derived from a machine learning algorithm called perceptron or multi layer perceptron that is gaining more and more attention nowadays because of its success in different fields like, computer vision to signal processing and medical diagnosis to self-driving cars. Like other AI algorithms, deep learning is based on decades of research. Nowadays, we have more and more data and cheap computing power that makes this algorithm really powerful in achieving state of the art accuracy. In modern world this algorithm is known as artificial neural network. Deep learning is much more accurate and robust compared to traditional artificial neural networks. But it is highly influenced by machine learning’s neural network and perceptron networks.

title: Dimension
content: Dimension for machine learning and data scientist is different from physics. Here, dimension of data means how many features you have in your data ocean(data-set). e.g in case of object detection application, flatten image size and color channel(e.g 28*28*3) is a feature of the input set. In case of house price prediction (maybe) house size is the data-set so we call it 1 dimentional data.

title: Epoch
content: An epoch describes the number of times the algorithm sees the entire data set.

title: Extrapolation
content: Making predictions outside the range of a dataset. E.g. My dog barks, so all dogs must bark. In machine learning we often run into trouble when we extrapolate outside the range of our training data.

title: False Positive Rate
content:
Defined as

\[FPR = 1 - Specificity = \frac{False Positives}{False Positives + True Negatives}\]
The False Positive Rate forms the x-axis of the ROC curve.

title: Feature
content: With respect to a dataset, a feature represents an attribute and value combination. Color is an attribute. “Color is blue” is a feature. In Excel terms, features are similar to cells. The term feature has other definitions in different contexts.

title: Feature Selection
content: Feature selection is the process of selecting relevant features from a data-set for creating a Machine Learning model.

title: Feature Vector
content: A list of features describing an observation with multiple attributes. In Excel we call this a row.

title: Gradient Accumulation
content: A mechanism to split the batch of samples—used for training a neural network—into several mini-batches of samples that will be run sequentially. This is used to enable using large batch sizes that require more GPU memory than available.

title: Hyperparameters
content: Hyperparameters are higher-level properties of a model such as how fast it can learn (learning rate) or complexity of a model. The depth of trees in a Decision Tree or number of hidden layers in a Neural Networks are examples of hyper parameters.

title: Induction
content: A bottoms-up approach to answering questions or solving problems. A logic technique that goes from observations to theory. E.g. We keep observing X, so we infer that Y must be True.

title: Instance
content: A data point, row, or sample in a dataset. Another term for observation.

title: Label
content: The “answer” portion of an observation in supervised learning. For example, in a dataset used to classify flowers into different species, the features might include the petal length and petal width, while the label would be the flower’s species.

title: Learning Rate
content: The size of the update steps to take during optimization loops like Gradient Descent. With a high learning rate we can cover more ground each step, but we risk overshooting the lowest point since the slope of the hill is constantly changing. With a very low learning rate, we can confidently move in the direction of the negative gradient since we are recalculating it so frequently. A low learning rate is more precise, but calculating the gradient is time-consuming, so it will take us a very long time to get to the bottom.

title: Loss
content: Loss = true_value(from data-set)- predicted value(from ML-model)  The lower the loss, the better a model (unless the model has over-fitted to the training data). The loss is calculated on training and validation and its interpretation is how well the model is doing for these two sets. Unlike accuracy, loss is not a percentage. It is a summation of the errors made for each example in training or validation sets.

title: Machine Learning
content: Mitchell (1997) provides a succinct definition: “A computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some class of tasks T and performance measure P, if its performance at tasks in T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.” In simple language machine learning is a field in which human made algorithms have an ability learn by itself or predict future for unseen data.

title: Model
content: A data structure that stores a representation of a dataset (weights and biases). Models are created/learned when you train an algorithm on a dataset.

title: Neural Networks
content: Neural Networks are mathematical algorithms modeled after the brain’s architecture, designed to recognize patterns and relationships in data.

title: Normalization
content: Restriction of the values of weights in regression to avoid overfitting and improving computation speed.

title: Noise
content: Any irrelevant information or randomness in a dataset which obscures the underlying pattern.

title: Null Accuracy
content: Baseline accuracy that can be achieved by always predicting the most frequent class (“B has the highest frequency, so lets guess B every time”).

title: Observation
content: A data point, row, or sample in a dataset. Another term for instance.

title: Outlier
content: An observation that deviates significantly from other observations in the dataset.

title: Overfitting
content: Overfitting occurs when your model learns the training data too well and incorporates details and noise specific to your dataset. You can tell a model is overfitting when it performs great on your training/validation set, but poorly on your test set (or new real-world data).

title: Parameters
content:
Parameters are properties of training data learned by training a machine learning model or classifier. They are adjusted using optimization algorithms and unique to each experiment.
Examples of parameters include:

weights in an artificial neural network
support vectors in a support vector machine
coefficients in a linear or logistic regression

title: Precision
content:
In the context of binary classification (Yes/No), precision measures the model’s performance at classifying positive observations (i.e. “Yes”). In other words, when a positive value is predicted, how often is the prediction correct? We could game this metric by only returning positive for the single observation we are most confident in.

\[P = \frac{True Positives}{True Positives + False Positives}\]

title: Recall
content:
Also called sensitivity. In the context of binary classification (Yes/No), recall measures how “sensitive” the classifier is at detecting positive instances. In other words, for all the true observations in our sample, how many did we “catch.” We could game this metric by always classifying observations as positive.

\[R = \frac{True Positives}{True Positives + False Negatives}\]

title: Recall vs Precision
content:
Say we are analyzing Brain scans and trying to predict whether a person has a tumor (True) or not (False). We feed it into our model and our model starts guessing.

Precision is the % of True guesses that were actually correct! If we guess 1 image is True out of 100 images and that image is actually True, then our precision is 100%! Our results aren’t helpful however because we missed 10 brain tumors! We were super precise when we tried, but we didn’t try hard enough.
Recall, or Sensitivity, provides another lens which with to view how good our model is. Again let’s say there are 100 images, 10 with brain tumors, and we correctly guessed 1 had a brain tumor. Precision is 100%, but recall is 10%. Perfect recall requires that we catch all 10 tumors!

title: Regression
content: Predicting a continuous output (e.g. price, sales).

title: Regularization
content: Regularization is a technique utilized to combat the overfitting problem. This is achieved by adding a complexity term to the loss function that gives a bigger loss for more complex models

title: Reinforcement Learning
content: Training a model to maximize a reward via iterative trial and error.

title: ROC (Receiver Operating Characteristic) Curve
content: A plot of the true positive rate against the false positive rate at all classification thresholds. This is used to evaluate the performance of a classification model at different classification thresholds. The area under the ROC curve can be interpreted as the probability that the model correctly distinguishes between a randomly chosen positive observation (e.g. “spam”) and a randomly chosen negative observation (e.g. “not spam”).

title: Segmentation
content: It is the process of partitioning a data set into multiple distinct sets. This separation is done such that the members of the same set are similar to each otherand different from the members of other sets.

title: Specificity
content:
In the context of binary classification (Yes/No), specificity measures the model’s performance at classifying negative observations (i.e. “No”). In other words, when the correct label is negative, how often is the prediction correct? We could game this metric if we predict everything as negative.

\[S = \frac{True Negatives}{True Negatives + False Positives}\]

title: Supervised Learning
content: Training a model using a labeled dataset.

title: Test Set
content: A set of observations used at the end of model training and validation to assess the predictive power of your model. How generalizable is your model to unseen data?

title: Training Set
content: A set of observations used to generate machine learning models.

title: Transfer Learning
content: A machine learning method where a model developed for a task is reused as the starting point for a model on a second task. In transfer learning, we take the pre-trained weights of an already trained model (one that has been trained on millions of images belonging to 1000’s of classes, on several high power GPU’s for several days) and use these already learned features to predict new classes.

title: True Positive Rate
content:
Another term for recall, i.e.

\[TPR = \frac{True Positives}{True Positives + False Negatives}\]
The True Positive Rate forms the y-axis of the ROC curve.

title: Type 1 Error
content: False Positives. Consider a company optimizing hiring practices to reduce false positives in job offers. A type 1 error occurs when candidate seems good and they hire him, but he is actually bad.

title: Type 2 Error
content: False Negatives. The candidate was great but the company passed on him.

title: Underfitting
content: Underfitting occurs when your model over-generalizes and fails to incorporate relevant variations in your data that would give your model more predictive power. You can tell a model is underfitting when it performs poorly on both training and test sets.

title: Universal Approximation Theorem
content: A neural network with one hidden layer can approximate any continuous function but only for inputs in a specific range. If you train a network on inputs between -2 and 2, then it will work well for inputs in the same range, but you can’t expect it to generalize to other inputs without retraining the model or adding more hidden neurons.

title: Unsupervised Learning
content: Training a model to find patterns in an unlabeled dataset (e.g. clustering).

title: Validation Set
content: A set of observations used during model training to provide feedback on how well the current parameters generalize beyond the training set. If training error decreases but validation error increases, your model is likely overfitting and you should pause training.

title: Variance
content:
How tightly packed are your predictions for a particular observation relative to each other?

Low variance suggests your model is internally consistent, with predictions varying little from each other after every iteration.
High variance (with low bias) suggests your model may be overfitting and reading too deeply into the noise found in every training set.
